{{Infobox organization |name = National Taxpayers Union |image= National Taxpayers Union (logo).png |caption = |membership = 362,000 |headquarters = [[Washington, DC]], [[United States|U.S.]] |formation = 1977 |budget = Revenue: $383,905
Expenses: $442,332
([[Fiscal year|FYE December 2013]]){{cite web|title=Charity Rating|url=http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=8563#.U649NI1dUQ4|publisher=[[Charity Navigator]]}} Also see {{cite web|title= GuideStar Summary: National Taxpayers Union |url=http://www.guidestar.org/organizations/52-1009116/national-taxpayers-union.aspx|publisher = [[GuideStar]] }} and {{cite web|title= GuideStar Summary: National Taxpayers Union Foundation |url=http://www.guidestar.org/organizations/52-1122683/national-taxpayers-union-foundation.aspx |publisher = [[GuideStar]] }} |endowment = |website = {{URL|http://www.ntu.org}} }} The '''National Taxpayers Union''' ('''NTU''') is a [[conservatism in the United States|conservative]]{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2014/06/old-trick-vs-blue-dog/|title=Old Trick vs. Blue Dog|date=June 20, 2014|website=[[Factcheck.org]]|publisher=Annenberg Public Policy Center}} taxpayers advocacy organization and [[Taxpayer groups|taxpayers union]] in the [[United States]], founded in 1977 by [[James Dale Davidson]]. NTU says that it is the largest and oldest grassroots taxpayer organization in the nation, with 362,000 members nationwide. It is closely affiliated with a non-profit foundation, the National Taxpayers Union Foundation (NTUF).{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntu.org/foundation/about|title=About the National Taxpayers Union Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=ntu.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite book|title=Lobbying in America: A Reference Handbook|last=Ronald J. Hrebenar, Bryson B. Morgan|first=|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2009|isbn=9781598841121|location=|pages=228}} NTUF is a non-partisan research and educational organization dedicated to showing Americans how taxes, government spending, and regulations affect them. The organization developed a method of determining how fiscally responsible members of congress are. This scale is used to determine how likely a member of congress is to vote responsibly in terms of finances. Some determining factors included are personal for instance, how many overdrawn personal checks the congressman has in a certain amount of time. While this may seem brash, the personal finance of congress members plays an important part in the grade they are assigned. Another particularly important factor in the grade is how the congress member votes on bills that the National Taxpayers Union sees fiscally important. Essentially the grade given to the politician determines how trustworthy he is in the eyes of the National Taxpayers Union.{{cite book|last1=Thorbecke, Matzelevich|first1=Willem, Sarah|title=Check Bouncing and Fiscal Irresponsibility: Evidence of Nonideological Shirking by Legislators|date=April 1995|publisher=Springer|location=New York|pages=60–64|edition=83|jstor=30026942}} The scale is also designed to accept both the point of view of conservative house members who want to balance the budget and liberal house members who would rather invest in commonwealth. ==Policy positions== The National Taxpayers Union has worked to enact constitutional limits on government taxes, spending and debt. The organization also played a role in Federal income tax indexing, so inflation no longer bumps taxpayers into higher brackets. It also worked for the passage of a [[Taxpayer Bill of Rights]]. The NTU favors either a [[Flat Tax]] or the [[FairTax]] (a national sales tax with rebate) for the United States, as opposed to the [[Income tax in the United States|current income tax system]].{{cite press release | title = To Compete in a Global Economy, U.S. Must Discard Backward-Looking Tax Policy, Study Concludes | publisher = National Taxpayers Union | date = 2005-09-14 | url = http://www.ntu.org/main/press_release.php?PressID=768&org_name=NTUF | accessdate = 2007-02-26 }} The organization argues in favor of the [[line-item veto]] for the president.{{cite press release | title = Taxpayer Group Delivers Reminder to Rushed Senators: "The Line-Item Veto – Don't Leave Town Without It!" | publisher = National Taxpayers Union | date = 2006-09-27 | url = http://www.ntu.org/main/press_release.php?PressID=872&org_name=NTU | accessdate = 2007-02-26 }} NTU generally opposes [[crop subsidies]] by the government (such as for sugar and ethanol).{{cite press release | title = Taxpayer Group Proposes Cures for Congress's Sugar-Subsidy "Sweet Tooth" | publisher = National Taxpayers Union | date = 2006-04-25 | url = http://www.ntu.org/main/press_release.php?PressID=834&org_name=NTU | accessdate = 2007-02-26 }} The organization's briefs and policy papers decry the [[Estate tax in the United States|federal estate tax]]{{cite press release | title = Senate Should Seize New Chance to Ditch the Death Tax, Nation's Largest Taxpayer Group Says | publisher = National Taxpayers Union | date = 2006-04-13 | url = http://www.ntu.org/main/press_release.php?PressID=827&org_name=NTU | accessdate = 2007-02-26 }} and support [[deregulation]].{{cite press release | title = Taxpayer Group Urges Congress to Scuttle Net Neutrality Legislation, Act Instead on Telecom Deregulation | date = 2006-05-24 | accessdate = 2007-02-26 | url = http://www.ntu.org/main/press_release.php?PressID=841&org_name=NTU | publisher = National Taxpayers Union }} NTU also provides information on "Congressional & Executive Pay/Perks" (e.g., NTU estimates the public pensions payments for Members of Congress),[http://www.ntu.org/main/faq.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820233416/http://www.ntu.org/main/faq.php |date=August 20, 2008 }} and NTU has called for reforms to deny a publicly funded pension to Members of Congress convicted of a felony.[http://www.ntu.org/pdf/L06%2011-28%20Congressional%20Pensions.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910045642/http://www.ntu.org/pdf/L06%2011-28%20Congressional%20Pensions.pdf |date=September 10, 2008 }} ==Legislation== ===Opposed=== * [[Temporary Debt Limit Extension Act (S. 540; 113th Congress)]] – a bill that would suspend the [[United States debt ceiling]] until March 15, 2015.{{cite news|last=Kasperowicz|first=Pete|title=House approves clean debt hike|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/198132-house-approves-clean-debt-ceiling-bill|accessdate=14 February 2014|newspaper=The Hill|date=11 February 2014}} The National Taxpayers Union opposed this bill and criticised politicians from both parties saying, "this year, as the limit approached, most Democrats refused to discuss the debt problem at all. Republicans opted to stress important, though mostly unrelated policy goals, thus failing to focus on the key issue at hand."{{cite web|title=NTU urges all Senators to vote "NO" on S. 540, the "Temporary Debt Limit Extension Act"|url=http://www.ntu.org/news-and-issues/budget-spending/senators-vote-no-s-540.html|publisher=National Taxpayers Union|accessdate=14 February 2014|date=12 February 2014}} NTU expressed the opinion that spending reforms should be dealt with, instead of just increasing the debt limit. ===Supported=== * [[Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2014 (S. 994; 113th Congress)]] – a bill that aims to make information on [[Expenditures in the United States federal budget|federal expenditures]] more easily accessible and transparent. The bill would require the [[United States Department of the Treasury|U.S. Department of the Treasury]] to establish common standards for financial data provided by all government agencies and to expand the amount of data that agencies must provide to the government website, USASpending.{{cite web|title=CBO – S. 994|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/44933|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=28 April 2014}} The NTU urged Representatives to vote in favor of the bill, saying that "this legislation would take an important step toward greater accountability to taxpayers by providing more information on how their hard-earned dollars are spent."{{cite web|title="YES" on S. 994, the Digital Accountability and Transparency (DATA) Act.|url=http://www.ntu.org/news-and-issues/budget-spending/yes-on-s-994-the-digital-accountability-and-transparency-act.html|publisher=National Taxpayers Union|accessdate=29 April 2014}} The NTU argued that "the DATA Act would bring increased transparency to a system that is too often rife with favoritism, waste, and fraud. As the federal government continues to make heavy demands on the public's paychecks, taxpayers deserve the opportunity to find out more details about how the money they send to Washington is being spent." * [[American Research and Competitiveness Act of 2014 (H.R. 4438; 113th Congress)]] – a bill that would amend the [[Internal Revenue Code]] to modify the calculation method and the rate for the [[Research & Experimentation Tax Credit|tax credit for qualified research expenses]] that expired at the end of 2013 and would make that modified credit permanent.{{cite web|title=CBO – H.R. 4438|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45324|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=6 May 2014}} NTU "urged" Representatives to vote in favor of the bill because it "would simplify and make permanent the 20 percent tax credit for research and development expenses."{{cite web|last=Swift|first=Nan|title=“YES” on H.R. 4438, the American Research and Competitiveness Act of 2014|url=http://www.ntu.org/news-and-issues/yes-on-hr-4438-05_07_2014.html|publisher=National Taxpayers Union|accessdate=7 May 2014|date=7 May 2014}} The NTU argued that making this tax credit permanent was "an important step toward creating a healthier business climate, providing broad-based relief, and promoting economic growth." The NTU also argued that it was important for the credit to become permanent because major research and development investments often take multiple years to do and it can be difficult to plan them when a tax credit is only going to last for one or two years. ==Activities== {{refimprove section|date=June 2014}} * [[Balanced Budget Amendment]] – NTU has been a proponent for a Balanced Budget Amendment (BBA) to the Constitution. * Government Spending Transparency – The National Taxpayers Union has been a proponent of the "Google Government" movement. More specifically, the organization calls for the creation of searchable Internet databases that provide information on state government grant and contract expenditures. NTU is a founding sponsor of www.ShowMeTheSpending.org, a website dedicated to online government spending transparency. * NTU Rates Congress – NTU rates U.S. Representatives and Senators on their congressional votes. NTU Rates Congress includes "every vote that significantly affects taxes, spending, debt, and regulatory burdens on consumers and taxpayers."[http://www.ntu.org/misc_items/rating/VS_2006.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829172623/http://www.ntu.org/misc_items/rating/VS_2006.pdf |date=August 29, 2008 }} NTU then assigns weights to the votes, reflecting the importance of each vote's effect on federal spending, when calculating each officials score. A grade of "A" indicates the organization views the member as a strong supporter of responsible{{Nonspecific|date=September 2010}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntu.org/ratecongress/page/2017-taxpayers-friend-award-winners|title=2017 Taxpayers' Friend Award Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=ntu.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=http://worldtaxpayers.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/StandingTogetherBooklet.pdf|title=Standing Together - How to Form a State or Local Taxpayer Group|last=Printed by the National Taxpayers Union|first=|date=|website=worldtaxpayers.org/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} tax and spending policies. The organization gives these members of Congress the "Taxpayers' Friend Award."[[Image:DeMint web.JPG|left|thumb|200px|Senator [[Jim DeMint]] receives Taxpayers' Friend Award, 2007]] * Research – NTU writes policy papers on many subjects they view as important to taxpayers. The organization also sends issue briefs to its members throughout the country outlining topics and issues that might be of interest to them. * NoTaxHikers.org – NTU launched www.NoTaxHikers.org in fall 2008. The site asks visitors to pledge not to vote for tax hikers. * Keep The Caps – NTU launched www.KeepTheCaps.com and BillionDollarBaseball.org in fall 2013. The campaign sought to foster grassroots support and pressure Congress to maintain the spending caps created in the [[Budget Control Act]] two years prior. ==History== {{refimprove section|date=June 2014}} [[James Dale Davidson]] began the organization in 1969. In 1977, the National Taxpayers Union Foundation was chartered to be the educational affiliate of the National Taxpayers Union in order to provide information about the benefits of lower taxes and limited government. In 1970, Davidson hired A. Earnest Fitzgerald, a [[United States Air Force]] analyst, as the president of NTU. In 1978, [[Grover Norquist]], was named executive director; after his departure in 1982, he was replaced by former Maryland State Senate Majority Leader [[George Snyder (politician)|George Snyder]]. In 1991, The National Taxpayers Union Foundation's signature project, the ''BillTally'', was started to reveal the legislative spending agendas of Members of Congress by analyzing the costs and savings of nearly every bill that they sponsor and cosponsor. BillTally provides the public, and media, with the only comprehensive look at how individual Members of Congress want to spend your tax dollars. In 1997, Davidson left NTU; [[John Berthoud]] was named president and served until his death in late 2007. Duane Parde was named president of the organization following the death of Berthoud. The current President of the National Taxpayers Union is Pete Sepp. Taking over the position in 1988, Sepp has made Congressional testimonies, policy papers, initiated tax revolts and played a role in the creation of the Balanced Budget Constitutional Amendment. Through appearances on Fox, CNN and CNBC as well as publications such as the Wall Street Journal and USA Today, Sepp has made a large impact over his time in the Presidency. He states, "We here at NTU promise to fight for taxpayers, so as to ensure that all Americans are able to pursue their dreams without the heavy hand of government holding them back." Together with board chair Rob Solt, and executive vice-president Brandon Arnold, the operations team of the National Taxpayers Union work towards favorable legislative outcomes for America's taxpayers such as less unnecessary government spending, tax reforms and free enterprise."National Taxpayers Union." GuideStar Profile. Accessed November 02, 2016. http://www.guidestar.org/profile/52-1009116. On April 15, 2009 hundreds of thousands of people around the country showed up at Tea Party Protests. They were protesting the new government spending plan proposed by the Obama administration. There was a National Taxpayers Union conference held from June 11–13 in 2009 held in Arlington, VA at the Hyatt Regency Crystal City Hotel. The convention was geared toward taxpayer activists who were working on taxpayer initiatives at a local and state level. The purpose of this conference was to keep the initiatives of the National Taxpayers Union alive and to get more of the public to understand their ideas.{{cite journal|last1=Engstrom|title=National Taxpayers Union: Fighting Tax and Spending Abuse.|date=18 May 2009|issue=18 Vol. 16|pages=1}} In 2009 at the National Taxpayers convention, former Ohio secretary of State Ken Blackwell and former Mississippi Governor Matt Blunt were guest speakers. ==See also== * [[Americans For Fair Taxation]] * [[Americans for Tax Reform]] * [[Citizens for Tax Justice]] * [[State Policy Network]] – a U.S. national network of free-market oriented think tanks of which NTU is an associate member * [[Tax Foundation]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ntu.org National Taxpayers Union website] * [http://nccsweb.urban.org/communityplatform/nccs/organization/profile/id/521009116/popup/1 National Taxpayers Union: Organizational Profile] – [[National Center for Charitable Statistics]] ([[Urban Institute]]) * [http://nccsweb.urban.org/communityplatform/nccs/organization/profile/id/521122683/popup/1 National Taxpayers Union Foundation: Organizational Profile] – [[National Center for Charitable Statistics]] ([[Urban Institute]]) {{coord|38.8057|N|77.0492|W|display=title}} [[Category:Political organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Taxation in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1969]] [[Category:New Right organizations (United States)]] [[Category:Taxpayer groups]]

Heindel''' (September 4, 1937) is an American chemist. He is the Howard S. Bunn Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at [[Lehigh University]], where he continues to do research.<ref name="Emeritus"/> Heindel also works as a medical research consultant.<ref name="Finn">{{cite web|last1=Finn|first1=John|title=Helen Murray Free Lectures Feature Pharmaceutical Expert|url=https://www.wooster.edu/news/releases/2015/october/lecture-murrayfree/|website=Wooster|date=1 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="Bowker"/><ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite web|title=Ned Heindel Ph.D.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=116696083&privcapId=28397097&previousCapId=30995038&previousTitle=20/20%20HealthCare%20Partners%20LLC|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> Heindel's research focuses on diagnostic and therapeutic drug development. He served as [[Presidents of the American Chemical Society|president of the American Chemical Society]] in 1994,<ref name="Carpenter">{{cite journal|last1=Carpenter|first1=Ernest|title=Ned Heindel chosen ACS president-elect|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=23 November 1992|volume=70|issue=47|pages=5–6|doi=10.1021/cen-v070n047.p005a|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/cen-v070n047.p005a|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> and has twice chaired the ACS Division for the History of Chemistry.<ref name="LehighBio"/>
== Early life == Ned Duane Heindel was born on September 4, l937 in [[Red Lion, York County, Pennsylvania]] to Mr. and Mrs. Penrose H. Heindel.<ref name="LehighBio"/><ref name="Bunn"/> He earned a B.S. in chemistry from [[Lebanon Valley College]] (1959), and a Master's degree (1961) and Ph.D. (1963) from the [[University of Delaware]],<ref name="Kaufman">{{cite news|last1=Kaufman|first1=Ron|title=People: Lehigh Professor Is Named Chemical Society's President-Elect|url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/16909/title/People--Lehigh-Professor-Is-Named-Chemical-Society-s-President-Elect/|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=The Scientist|date=January 11, 1993}}</ref> where he worked with William A. Mosher.<ref name="Emeritus"/> He did postdoctoral work at [[Princeton University]] in 1964<ref name="Safety">{{cite book|last1=Committee on Promoting Safe and Secure Chemical Management in Developing Countries, Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology, Division on Earth and Life Studies, National Research Council of the National Academies|title=Promoting chemical laboratory safety and security in developing countries|date=2010|publisher=National Academies Press|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=0309150418|pages=75|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4KYzOUrr9lsC&pg=PT91|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> with [[Edward C. Taylor]].<ref name="Emeritus"/>
== Career == After teaching briefly at [[Ohio University]] and [[Marshall University]] Heindel joined the faculty at [[Lehigh University]] in 1966. He became a full professor by 1973,<ref name="Emeritus"/> and was named the Howard S. Bunn Distinguished Professor of Organic Chemistry in 1976.<ref name="Bowker">{{cite book|title=American men & women of science, 1995-96 : a biographical directory of today's leaders in physical, biological and related sciences|date=1996|publisher=R. R. Bowker|location=New Providence, New Jersey|isbn=0835234665|volume=3|pages=739–740|edition=19th}}</ref><ref name="Henderson">{{cite book |editor-last1=Henderson |editor-first1=Andrea Kovacs |chapter=Heindel, Ned Duane |title=American Men & Women of Science: A Biographical Directory of Today's Leaders in Physical, Biological, and Related Sciences |date=2010 |publisher=Gale|volume=3 |location=Detroit |page=701 |edition=28th |url=http://link.galegroup.com/apps/doc/CX2469848565/GVRL?u=othmerloc&sid=GVRL&xid=2711e7b2 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Bunn">{{cite news|title=Awarded Chemistry Recognition DR. NED D. HEINDEL RED LION|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/81585658/|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=York Daily Record from York, Pennsylvania|agency=|page=6|date=June 2, 1976}}</ref>
Heindel also served as a Visiting Professor of Radiation Oncology at [[Hahnemann University Hospital]] from 1971-2006, and as Director of the Center for Health Sciences at Lehigh University from 1980-1987. He helped to establish the Lehigh-Hahnemann Cooperative Medical Education Program from 1992-2017 and was involved in Lehigh's Distance Education program.<ref name="Emeritus"/>
Heindel became professor emeritus in 2018. He continues to do research (e.g. healing burn wounds<ref>{{cite web |title=Newletter of the Lehigh Valley Section |date= October 2018 |volume=101 |number=7 |page=2 |url= https://lvacs.sites.acs.org/Octagons/October2018.pdf |website= American Chemical Society, Lehigh Valley Section |accessdate= 5 October 2018}}</ref>) and works as a medical research consultant.<ref name="Emeritus">{{cite news |title= Transitioning into a renewed focus on excellence |url= https://chemistry.cas2.lehigh.edu/sites/chemistry.cas2.lehigh.edu/files/doc-newsletter-f18-no48-9-25-18-min.pdf |accessdate= 5 October 2018 |pages=4-5, 18 |work= MUDD in your eye |agency= Lehigh University, Department of Chemistry |issue=Fall |date=2018}}</ref>
===Science=== Heindel's research focuses on diagnostic and therapeutic drug development, including the areas of [[cancer]] research, [[nuclear medicine]], diagnostic [[Radiopharmacology|radioactive pharmaceuticals]],<ref name="Bowker"/><ref>{{cite book |editor-last1=Heindel |editor-first1=Ned D. |title=The Chemistry of radiopharmaceuticals |date=1978 |publisher=Masson Pub. USA |location=New York |isbn=0893520195}}</ref><ref name="Welch">{{cite book |last1=Welch |first1=Michael J. |title=Radiopharmaceuticals and Other Compounds Labelled with Short-Lived Radionuclides |date=September 24, 2013 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=1483104168 |page=77 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TvD8BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA77&dq=Heindel+radiopharmaceuticals&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi5-eeEos7bAhXD5YMKHQZ8BhsQ6AEIOjAD#v=onepage&q=Heindel%20radiopharmaceuticals&f=false |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> [[chemotherapeutics]] and tumor-associated [[monoclonal antibodies]].<ref name="CounterACT">{{cite web|title=Ned D. Heindel, Ph.D.|url=http://counteract.rutgers.edu/faculty/heindel.html|website=UMDNJ-Rutgers University CounterACT Research Center of Excellence|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> He has applied for at least 20 patents, with 14 issued.<ref name="Emeritus"/><ref name="Safety"/><ref name="Justia">{{cite web|title=Patents by Inventor Ned D. Heindel|url=https://patents.justia.com/inventor/ned-d-heindel|website=Justia Patents|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> He has published more than 260 papers.<ref name="Emeritus"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Ned D. Heindel|url=https://chemistry.cas2.lehigh.edu/faculty/ned-d-heindel|website=Lehigh University|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> A number of candidate pharmaceuticals from his lab have reached advanced animal trials.<ref name="Salter">{{cite news |last1=Salter |first1=Rosa |title=Lehigh Professor's Patent Pays Off For Blood Sterilization |url=http://articles.mcall.com/1995-08-28/features/3047830_1_blood-banks-blood-cells-sterilization |accessdate=11 June 2018 |work=The Morning Call |date=August 28, 1995}}</ref><ref name="Joseph"/>
Heindel has shown that [[psoralens]] and [[coumarins]] can be useful as photoactivated inhibitors of [[epidermal growth factor]].<ref name="Bourke, Jr.">{{cite web |last1=Bourke, Jr. |first1=Frederic A. |title=US20140341845A1: Methods and systems for treating cell proliferation related disorders |url=https://patents.google.com/patent/US20140341845 |website=US Patents |accessdate=11 June 2018|quote="U.S. Pat. No. 5,216,176 of Heindel discloses a large number of psoralens and coumarins that have some effectiveness as photoactivated inhibitors of epidermal growth factor. Halogens and amines are included among the vast functionalities that could be included in the psoralen/coumarin backbone."}}</ref><ref name="Acton">{{cite book |last1=Acton |first1=Q. Ashton |title=Advances in DNA Research and Application |date=June 21, 2013 |publisher=Scholarly Editions |location=Atlanta, Georgia |isbn=1481682350 |page=169 |edition=2013 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F57riHYkx74C&pg=PA169 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Choudhuri">{{cite journal |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |last2=Choudhuri |first2=Mridula |last3=Ressner |first3=Joel |last4=Foster |first4=Natalie |title=Aminomethyl psoralens. Electrophilic substitution of hydroxymethylphthalimide on linear furocoumarins |journal=Journal of Heterocyclic Chemistry |date=January 1985 |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=73–76 |doi=10.1002/jhet.5570220119 |url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/jhet.5570220119}}</ref><ref name="Van Dongen">{{cite journal |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |last2=Van Dongen |first2=Jacobus M.A.M. |last3=Sachais |first3=Bruce S. |last4=Phillips |first4=John H. |last5=Gallo |first5=Michael A. |last6=Laskin |first6=Jeffrey D. |title=Syntheses of Psoralen Analogues and Evaluation of Their Inhibition of Epidermal Growth Factor Binding |journal=Journal of Pharmaceutical Sciences |date=July 1991 |volume=80 |issue=7 |pages=686–689 |doi=10.1002/jps.2600800715 |url=https://jpharmsci.org/article/S0022-3549(15)48584-3/pdf |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> [[Photosensitizers]] are used to treat epidermal proliferation, [[psoriasis]] and [[vitiligo]]. Heindel's lab has identified a new structural family of organic molecules which perform as light-activated anti-cancer compounds. After activation by [[ultraviolet light]], lipophilic dipyranone (NDH2476) was found to inhibit abnormal [[Keratinocyte]] growth with an IC50 of 9 nanomolar concentration. NDH2476 acts through initial [[Intercalation (biochemistry)|intercalation into DNA]] and when irradiated, “nicks” the [[polynucleotide]] and prevents subsequent unwinding. Gem di-methylation, double bond [[hydrogenation]], or non-linear, angular geometry to the dipyranone greatly reduced or even eliminated the photo-cytotoxicity.<ref name="Laskin">{{cite journal |last1=Laskin |first1=Jeffrey D. |last2=Jan |first2=Yi-Hua |last3=Jetter |first3=Michele M. |last4=Guillon |first4=Christophe D. |last5=Mariano |first5=Thomas M. |last6=Heck |first6=Diane E. |last7=Heindel |first7=Ned D. |title=Identification of a Pyranocoumarin Photosensitizer that is a Potent Inhibitor of Keratinocyte Growth |journal=Photochemistry and Photobiology |date=May 2018 |volume=94 |issue=3 |pages=577–582 |doi=10.1111/php.12882 |pmid=29315592 }}</ref>
Heindel is one of the principal investigators in Project CounterACT-Rutgers, studying antidotes to [[sulfur mustard]] gas poisoning.<ref name="Lally">{{cite news|last1=Lally|first1=Robin|title=Rutgers Receives $19 Million to Develop Drugs to Treat Chemical Weapons Attacks Work aimed at devising drug therapies to counteract deadly chemical poisons|url=https://news.rutgers.edu/news/rutgers-receives-19-million-develop-drugs-treat-chemical-weapons-attacks/20161130|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=Rutgers Today|date=December 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Safety"/> Heindel's lab has developed an [[indomethacin]] [[prodrug]], NDH4338, designed for use as a wound-healing accelerant for [[vesicant]]-triggered [[skin lesions]]. The drug is a trifunctional pharmaceutical composed of covalently linked inhibitors of [[COX-2]], [[acetylcholinesterase]], and induced [[nitric oxide synthase]] which can be released [[in vivo]] from the parent molecule. It has been tested on rodents pre-exposed to chloroethyl ethyl sulfide, [[nitrogen mustard]], and sulfur mustard and has shown a marked acceleration of wound healing. While NDH4338 has several mechanisms of action, a principle one is suppression of [[mast cell]] [[degranulation]] in skin.<ref name="Joseph">{{cite journal |last1=Joseph |first1=Laurie B. |last2=Composto |first2=Gabriella M. |last3=Perez |first3=Roberto M. |last4=Kim |first4=Hong-Duck |last5=Casillas |first5=Robert P. |last6=Heindel |first6=Ned D. |last7=Young |first7=Sherri C. |last8=Lacey |first8=Carl J. |last9=Saxena |first9=Jaya |last10=Guillon |first10=Christophe D. |last11=Croutch |first11=Claire R. |last12=Laskin |first12=Jeffrey D. |last13=Heck |first13=Diane E. |title=Sulfur mustard induced mast cell degranulation in mouse skin is inhibited by a novel anti-inflammatory and anticholinergic bifunctional prodrug |journal=Toxicology Letters |date=September 2018 |volume=293 |pages=77–81 |doi=10.1016/j.toxlet.2017.11.005 |pmid=29127031 }}</ref><ref name="Lacey">{{cite journal |last1=Lacey |first1=Carl J. |last2=Wohlman |first2=Irene |last3=Guillon |first3=Christophe |last4=Saxena |first4=Jaya |last5=Fianu-Velgus |first5=Cynthia |last6=Aponte |first6=Erik |last7=Young |first7=Sherri C. |last8=Heck |first8=Diane E. |last9=Joseph |first9=Laurie B. |last10=Laskin |first10=Jeffrey D. |last11=Heindel |first11=Ned D. |title=Multi-inhibitor prodrug constructs for simultaneous delivery of anti-inflammatory agents to mustard-induced skin injury |journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences |date=August 2016 |volume=1378 |issue=1 |pages=174–179 |doi=10.1111/nyas.13177 |pmc=5063683 }}</ref>
[[Hydroxamate]] compounds developed by Heindel's lab have been found to enhance [[corneal]] wound healing after mustard exposure. Compounds studied include olvanil OH (NDH4409) and retro olvanil 8 (NDH4417). Hydroxamates reduced the activity of [[ADAM17]] and [[matrix metalloproteinases]] (MMPs), and attenuated expression of [[EMMPRIN]], a tumor cell surface inducer of MMPs. This resulted in less epithelial sloughing, improved protection of the [[basement membrane zone]], and better epithelial-stromal integrity after injury.<ref name="Gordon">{{cite journal |last1=Gordon |first1=Marion |last2=Rodrigues |first2=Andrea |last3=Hahn |first3=Rita |last4=Gerecke |first4=Donald |last5=Svoboda |first5=Kathy |last6=Heindel |first6=Ned |title=Corneal Wound Healing is Facilitated by Hydroxamates that Reduce EMMPRIN Expression |journal=Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science |date=June 2013 |volume=54 |page=3910 |url=http://iovs.arvojournals.org/article.aspx?articleid=2148730 |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
Heindel serves on the Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Drug Discovery Institute,<ref name="PDDI">{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.padrugdiscovery.org/aboutus/boardofdirectors.html|website=Pennsylvania Drug Discovery Institute|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> and the Scientific Advisory Board of Azevan Pharmaceuticals, Inc.<ref name="Bloomberg"/>
Heindel has held a number of positions in the [[American Chemical Society]] (ACS), since first becoming a board member in 1985.<ref name="Carpenter"/> In 1994, Heindel served as President of the ACS.<ref name="BD">{{cite web|title=ACS Presidents, A Chronological List|url=https://www.acs.org/content/acs/en/about/president/acspresidents.html|website=American Chemical Society|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="Wilson">{{cite journal|last1=Wilson|first1=Elizabeth|title=Luminaries highlight chemistry's contributions|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=8 February 1999|volume=77|issue=6|pages=38|doi=10.1021/cen-v077n006.p038a}}</ref> In 2009 Heindel was named an ACS Fellow.<ref name="Fellow">{{cite web|title=ACS Fellows|url=https://www.acs.org/content/dam/acsorg/funding/fellows/acs-fellows-list.xlsx|website=|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref>
===History=== Heindel has served on the Board of Directors of the National Foundation for History of Chemistry,<ref name="Achilladelis">{{cite book|last1=Achilladelis|first1=Basil|last2=Bowden|first2=Mary Ellen|title=Structures of Life: To Accompany an Exhibit by the Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry|date=1989|publisher=Beckman Center for the History of Chemistry|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=978-0-941901-07-9|page=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DhlU3sJYb_8C&pg=PA37|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> and has twice been chairperson of the ACS Division of the History of Chemistry.<ref name="LehighBio">{{cite web|title=Biography: Ned Heindel|url=http://nheindel.cas2.lehigh.edu/content/biography|website=Lehigh University|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> In 1979, Heindel chaired a task force formed by the ACS to consider the creation of a national center for the history of chemistry. In December 1981 the ACS approved the establishment of the [[Chemical Heritage Foundation|Center for the History of Chemistry]] in Philadelphia.<ref name=HistoryCHF>{{cite journal|title=The History of CHF|journal=Chemical Heritage: Newsmagazine of the Chemical Heritage Foundation|date=2000-02-01|volume=18|issue=1|pages=16–22}}</ref><ref name=CHOC18-3>{{cite journal|last=Wotiz|first=John H.|title=History of Chemistry: The ACS Centre in Philadelphia |journal=Chemical Heritage|date=2000|volume=18|issue=3|pages=45–46}}</ref><ref name=CHF-origin>{{cite web|last=Gussman|first=Neil|title=The Power of John C. Haas's Good Name|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2011-05-16-john-c-haas.aspx|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=23 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712182325/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/history/chf-founders/2011-05-16-john-c-haas.aspx|archivedate=July 12, 2016}}</ref> He was a contributor to a [[Nova (TV series)|NOVA]] program about [[Percy Julian]], “Forgotten Genius”, which aired in 2007.<ref name="Emeritus"/>
Heindel has written both papers and books relating history and chemistry. Among his publications he has examined "The Professionalization of American Chemistry: How the German Ph.D. Model Crossed the Atlantic",<ref name="Rasmussen">{{cite book |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |last2=Sturchio |first2=Jeffrey L. |last3=Bohning |first3=James J. |editor-last=Rasmussen |editor-first=Seth C. |title=Igniting the Chemical Ring of Fire |date=2018 |publisher=World Scientific |location=New Jersey |isbn=978-1-78634-454-0 |pages=387–426|chapter=Chapter 14: The Professionalization of American Chemistry: How the German Ph.D. Model Crossed the Atlantic |url=https://www.worldscientific.com/doi/abs/10.1142/9781786344557_0014 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> and the careers of early [[photochemistry|photochemists]] such as [[Giacomo Ciamician]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |last2=Pfau |first2=Michel A. |title=A profitable partnership: Giacomo Ciamician and Paul Silber |journal=Journal of Chemical Education |date=July 1965 |volume=42 |issue=7 |pages=383 |doi=10.1021/ed042p383}}</ref>
Another area of interest is the medicinal chemistry and folk-healing techniques of the [[Pennsylvania Dutch]]. ''The Nineteenth Century Horse Doctor: A Pennsylvania Dutchman’s Practical Guide to Treating Horses'' recognized the essential role of the horse in pre-industrial North American farming. Heindel and Robert D. Rapp translate and examine recipes in 19th century books of veterinary practice, or "Pferdartz", from the Moravian and the Pennsylvania Dutch traditions. Folk medicine cures ranged from herbs, minerals, poultices, and bleeding to incantations.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Nineteenth Century Horse Doctor: A Pennsylvania Dutchman's Practical Guide to Treating Horses |url=http://coffeetownpress.com/the-nineteenth-century-horse-doctor-a-pennsylvania-dutchmans-practical-guide-to-treating-horses/ |website=Coffeetown Press |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="Rapp">{{cite book |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |last2=Rapp |first2=Robert D. |title=The Nineteenth-century horse doctor : a Pennsylvania Dutchman's practical guide for treating horses |date=2011 |publisher=Coffeetown Press |location=Seattle, WA |isbn=9781603811217}}</ref>
In ''Hexenkopf, History, Healing and Hexerei'', he examines traditions of both white and black magic in the Wilhelm and Saylor families of [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania]]. Healers such as [[Johann Peter Seilor]]<ref name="White">{{cite book |last1=White |first1=Thomas |title=Witches of Pennsylvania : occult history & lore |date=2013 |publisher=Arcadia Publishing |isbn=978-1626191327 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=riiACQAAQBAJ&pg=PT39}}</ref> and [[Emanuel Wilhelm]] used tonics, personalized prescriptions and manipulations to treat sickness and fight off evil in the tradition of white magic or "[[Braucherei]]". Modern pharmaceutical science has examined the use of some of their treatments such as [[poke root]] and [[mayapple]] root.<ref name="Bentley">{{cite news |last1=Bentley |first1=Tiffany |title=Witchcraft in Williams Township, a history of the good and evil |url=http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/events/index.ssf/2011/10/witchcraft_in_williams_townshi.html |accessdate=11 June 2018 |work=Lehigh Valley Live |date=Oct 29, 2011}}</ref> Traditions of black magic have focused on [[Hexenkopf Hill|Hexenkopf Rock]].<ref name="Merlin">{{cite news |last1=Merlin |first1=Michelle |title=Haunted rock legends live on in technology, religion |url=https://www.apnews.com/079df2401a384304a5eaebefbf30ebaa |accessdate=11 June 2018 |work=AP |date=October 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Heindel |first1=Ned D. |title=Hexenkopf: History, Healing and Hexerei |date=2009 |publisher=Northampton County Historical and Genealogical Society |isbn=978-1877701177 |edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=On the Shelf: Hexenkopf: History, Healing and Hexerei |url=https://danharms.wordpress.com/2006/08/07/on-the-shelf-hexenkopf-history-healing-and-hexerei/ |website=Papers Falling from an Attic Window |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Heindel and his wife Linda (Heefner) Heindel are active in historical groups in the [[Lehigh Valley]]<ref name="Folklife">{{cite journal|title=Contributors|url=http://digitalcommons.ursinus.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1134&context=pafolklifemag|accessdate=10 October 2017|journal=Pennsylvania Folklife Magazine|volume=41|issue=3|date=1992}}</ref> and frequently contribute to ''Pennsylvania Folklife Magazine''.<ref name="Ursinus">{{cite web|title=Pennsylvania Folklife Magazine|url=http://digitalcommons.ursinus.edu/pafolklifemag/index.2.html|website=Digital Commons at Ursinus|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> Heindel has lectured on social relationships between Europeans, [[Lenni Lenape]], and [[Shawnee]] in the [[Durham, Pennsylvania|Durham area]] in the 1700s. He is interested in the work of the Buckwampum Historical and Literary Society,<ref name="Sigafoos">{{cite book|title=Bucks County Historical Society Papers|last=Sigafoos|first=Lewis|publisher=Bucks Country Historical Society|year=1935|editor-last=Fackenthal|editor-first=B.F.|volume=7|pages=414–419|language=eng|chapter=Buckwampum Historical and LIterary Society|ref=harv|chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/buckscountyhisto07buck#page/414/mode/2up}}</ref> an group that met from 1888 to 1903. Most were amateurs but archaeologist [[Henry Mercer]] was also a member. The group conducted several digs in [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania]] and [[Northampton County, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Clark">{{cite news |last1=Clark |first1=Kathryn Finegan |title=Once upon a time in Durham |url=http://www.buckscountyherald.com/7-12-18/By-the-Way.html |accessdate=16 July 2018 |work=Bucks County Herald |date=2018}}</ref>
==Land conservation== Over a 50 year period, Ned and Linda Heindel have purchased and preserved 128 acres of "forest, bogs and meadows" around the stone farmhouse in which they live, in [[Williams Township, Northampton County, Pennsylvania]]. The hilly area includes stands of ash, poplar and oak trees, wild [[azalea]], freshwater springs and [[Hexenkopf Hill|Hexenkopf Rock]], a ridge of exposed [[Precambrian]] stone.<ref name="Kraus"/> Linda Heindel serves as the secretary of the Land Preservation Board of Williams Township, Northampton County, PA.<ref name="TWP">{{cite web|title=Land Preservation Board|url=https://www.williamstwp.org/land-preservation/board|website=Williams Township, Northampton County, PA|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
As of August 2014, a consortium of energy companies announced plans to build the [[PennEast Pipeline]] to carry [[natural gas]] from the [[Marcellus Shale]] in Pennsylvania into [[New Jersey]]. Ned and Linda Heindel are among residents who would be affected.<ref name="Kraus">{{cite news|last1=Kraus|first1=Scott|last2=Palochko|first2=Jacqueline|title=Proposed 105-mile PennEast pipeline rattles residents|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/local/mc-penneast-pipeline-residents-20141004-story.html|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=The Morning Call|date=October 14, 2014}}</ref>
Beginning on February 6, 2018, the PennEast Pipeline Co. has filed [[eminent domain]] notices in federal court to take possession of rights of way on the lands of those who have not agreed to the pipeline.<ref name="Hurdle">{{cite news|last1=Hurdle|first1=Jon|title=PennEast pipeline seeks eminent domain, plus U.S. marshals to protect workers|url=https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/02/08/penneast-pipeline-seeks-eminent-domain-plus-u-s-marshals-to-protect-workers/|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=StateImpact|agency=NPR|date=February 8, 2018}}</ref> Those who received eminent domain notices include at least 129 New Jersey landowners<ref name="Hurdle3">{{cite news|last1=Hurdle|first1=Jon|title=Pipeline Conflict Heats Up: Landowners Vow to Fight PennEast on Eminent Domain|url=http://www.njspotlight.com/stories/18/02/14/pipeline-conflict-heats-up-landowners-vow-to-fight-penneast-on-eminent-domain/|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=NJ Spotlight|date=February 15, 2018}}</ref> and 50 Pennsylvania landowners,<ref name="Hurdle2">{{cite news|last1=Hurdle|first1=Jon|title=Landowners brace for eminent domain loss in PennEast pipeline cases|url=https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2018/02/19/landowners-brace-for-eminent-domain-loss-in-penneast-pipeline-cases/|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=StateImpact|agency=NPR|date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> among them the Heindels.<ref name="Wright">{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Emma|title=Residents fight for their land against PennEast pipeline|url=http://www.wfmz.com/news/lehigh-valley/residents-fight-for-their-land-against-penneast-pipeline/704851068|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=69 News|date=February 20, 2018}}</ref> The Heindels are active opponents of the proposed pipeline and the attempted seizure of their land under eminent domain.<ref name="Palochko">{{cite news|last1=Palochko|first1=Jacqueline|title=Newsmaker Q&A: Linda Heindel, PennEast Pipeline opponent|url=http://www.mcall.com/news/local/mc-newsmaker-linda-heindel-20141108-story.html|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=The Morning Call|date=November 9, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Kraus"/><ref name="Wright"/>
==Awards== * 2011, Hillman Faculty Award, Lehigh University, for educational and research achievements <ref>{{cite web|title=Hillman Faculty Award|url=https://awards.web.lehigh.edu/node/4|website=University Awards|publisher=Lehigh University|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="PDDI"/> * 2009, Fellow, [[American Chemical Society]]<ref name="Fellow"/> * 2002, Ben Franklin Partnership Award for Corporate Assistance<ref name="Berg">{{cite news|last1=Berg|first1=Christian|title=Ben Franklin Technology center honors eight leaders for contribution to economy|url=http://articles.mcall.com/2002-05-17/business/3407089_1_ben-franklin-technology-partners-glemser-technologies-raymond-glemser|work=The Morning Call|date=May 17, 2002}}</ref> * 1997, [[Henry Aaron Hill|Henry Hill]] Award for Achievements in Medicinal Chemistry, [[NOBCChE]]<ref name="NOBCChE">{{cite web|title=Dr. Henry A. Hill Distinguished Lecture|url=http://www.nobcche.org/henry-hill-distinguished-lecture|website=National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> * 1996, [[Harry Stone Mosher|Harry and Carol Mosher]] Award for Contributions to Chemistry, ACS<ref>{{cite web|title=Section Awards and Grants|url=http://scvacs.org/?page_id=44|website=American Chemical Society|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> * 1989, Brady Cancer Achievement Award, Brady Cancer Research Foundation, for research in tumor-imaging radiopharmaceuticals<ref name="Bowker"/><ref name="PDDI"/> * 1978, Briody Award<ref name="Henderson"/> * 1969, Robinson Award<ref name="Henderson"/>

{{Orphan|date=September 2015}}
{{Infobox court case | name = Neilson v A-G | court = [[Court of Appeal of New Zealand]] | date_filed = | image = Coat of arms of New Zealand.svg | date decided = 3 May 2001 Richardson P, Gault, Thomas, Keith, McGrath JJ | full name = Neilson v A-G | citations = [2001] 3 NZLR 433 | judges = [[Ivor Richardson|Richardson P]], [[Thomas Gault|Gault J]], [[Ted Thomas (judge)|Thomas J]], [[Kenneth Keith|Keith J]], [[John McGrath (judge)|McGrath J]] | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | Keywords = negligence }} '''Neilson v A-G''' [2001] 3 NZLR 433 is a cited case in New Zealand regarding suing under the [[New Zealand Bill of Rights Act 1990|Bill of Rights Act]] for unlawful arrest.<ref name="McLay">{{cite book |title=Butterworths Student Companion Torts |edition=4th |last1=McLay |first1=Geoff |publisher=LexisNexis |ISBN=0-408-71686-X|year=2003 |page=}}</ref>
==Background== After Neilson was dismissed from his job as a private investigator, he subsequently won a personal grievance in the Employment Court against his former employer.
Part of the employers unsuccessful defence was that Neilson had pocketed some fees from one of their clients.
Eight days after losing in the Employment Court, the employer lodged a complaint with the police regarding the misappropriated money.
The police, without doing a proper investigation, and despite evidence that would suggest that no crime had occurred, a police office arrested Neilson without first obtaining an arrest warrant.
Later, Neilson was discharged without conviction, and sued the police for wrongful arrest, and was awarded $10,000 in damages.
The police appealed.
==Held== The court ruled that the arrest was still illegal, but did reduce the damages award to $5,000.

'''Ninon Colneric''' (born 1948) is a German former judge at the [[European Court of Justice]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.streit-fem.de/media/documents/1264356546.pdf?PHPSESSID=pitqc59osuda58guq5r01rlbv4|title=Ninon Colneric: Richterin am EuGH|author=Dagmar Schiek|page=188|language=German|trans-title=''Ninon Colneric: Judge at ECJ|format=|accessdate=2010-05-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719085824/http://www.streit-fem.de/media/documents/1264356546.pdf?PHPSESSID=pitqc59osuda58guq5r01rlbv4|archivedate=2011-07-19|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.taz.de/1/archiv/archiv/?dig=2006/06/07/a0081 |title='SPD opfert eine Richterin für Angela Merkel|author= Dagmar Schiek|date=7 June 2006|work=Die Tageszeitung (taz.de)|page=188|language=German|trans-title=''Ninon Colneric: Judge at ECJ|accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref>
Born in [[Oer-Erkenschwick]], she studied legal science in [[Tübingen]], [[Munich]] and [[Geneva]]. Following a period of academic research in London, she was awarded a doctorate in law by the [[University of Munich]]. She was authorised, by the [[University of Bremen]], to teach [[labour law]], [[sociology of law]] and social law. She was professor [[ad interim]] at the faculty of law of the universities of Frankfurt, and [[Bremen]]. She was president of the Landesarbeitsgericht [[Schleswig-Holstein]] (1989).
She was a judge at the Labour Court (''Arbeitsgericht'') [[Oldenburg]].
She collaborated, as an expert, on the European Expertise Service ([[European Union]]) project for the reform of the labour law of [[Kirghizstan]] (1994 to 1995). She was an honorary Professor at the [[University of Bremen]] in labour law, specifically in European labour law.<ref>[http://www.jura.uni-bremen.de/typo3/cms405/index.php?id=208 University of Bremen, Webpage.]</ref> Presently, she is Co-Dean at the [[China-EU School of Law]], a cooperative project between a consortium of European universities and the [[China University of Political Science and Law]].<ref>[http://www.faz.net/s/Rub877FB5820A42474CA842CA0B010E339D/Doc~E4562ED0EB7E44299AF4167FA19E408EC~ATpl~Ecommon~Scontent.html ''Die Entwicklungshelferin.''] FAZ, 8. März 2010.</ref>

{{Insolvency}} '''Personal bankruptcy''' law allows, in certain [[jurisdiction]]s, an [[individual]] to be declared [[bankruptcy|bankrupt]]. Virtually every country with a modern [[law|legal]] system features some form of debt relief for individuals. Personal bankruptcy is distinguished from corporate bankruptcy.
==By country== The DICE report 2006 of Munich's ifo Economic Research compared international personal bankruptcy in selected OECD-countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Detailinformationen zur Publikation|url=http://www.cesifo-group.de/de/ifoHome/publications/docbase/details.html?docId=14567419|accessdate=19 April 2014|language=German}}</ref>
===United States=== {{see also|Bankruptcy in the United States#Personal bankruptcy}} In the United States, the same chapters of the [[United States Bankruptcy Code|Bankruptcy Code]] are applied in both personal and corporate bankruptcies. Most individuals who enter bankruptcy do so under [[Chapter 13, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 13]] (a "reorganization" plan) or [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] (a "liquidation" of debtor's assets). More rarely, personal bankruptcy proceedings are carried out under [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=How Does Bankruptcy Work|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/bankruptcy/bankruptcy.html|website=ExpertLaw.com|publisher=ExpertLaw|accessdate=15 May 2017}}</ref> The ultimate goal of personal bankruptcy, from the viewpoint of the debtor, is receiving a [[bankruptcy discharge|discharge]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Discharge in Bankruptcy - Bankruptcy Basics|url=http://www.uscourts.gov/services-forms/bankruptcy/bankruptcy-basics/discharge-bankruptcy-bankruptcy-basics|website=United States Courts|publisher=Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts|accessdate=15 May 2017}}</ref>
===Canada=== The concept behind [[bankruptcy in Canada]] is that an individual assigns (surrender) everything they own to a [[Licensed Insolvency Trustee|trustee in bankruptcy]] in exchange for the elimination of their [[unsecured debts]].
The rules for filing personal bankruptcy in each province and territory differ slightly. In some areas of Canada individuals may be permitted to keep (exempt) certain property. Common items for exemption include clothing, furniture, appliances, motor vehicles, medical and dental aids, a home, family [[heirloom]]s, and some insurance. In basic terms, any property the debtor might require to survive can be exempt. Personal Bankruptcy will eliminate most, if not all, of an individual’s debt, but it also impacts their future ability to obtain credit.
The cost of personal bankruptcy in Canada depends on the individual’s monthly family income, the size of the family, and their assets (such as RRSPs). An alternative to personal bankruptcy (in Canada) is a Consumer Proposal. Another option in Canada is a debt consolidation. No matter what option they choose, they can often turn to a trustee in bankruptcy for a free consultation.
===Israel=== Personal bankruptcy in Israel is governed by the Bankruptcy Ordinance, 1980.<ref name="Niemi-KiesiläinenRamsay2003">{{citation|author1=Johanna Niemi-Kiesiläinen|author2=Iain Ramsay|author3=William C. Whitford|title=Consumer Bankruptcy in Global Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-S7UWhRvNjUC|date=1 January 2003|isbn=978-1-84113-358-4}}</ref> Debtors and their creditors may apply to the court for bankruptcy. If it is granted, an automatic stay enters into force and a trustee (frequently the Official Receiver) is appointed for the debtor's assets. The automatic stay does not bar [[secured creditor]]s' lien enforcement. Bona fide debtors usually receive a discharge either immediately (if they have practically no assets) or within several months to several years from the onset of proceedings (during which time the debtor is mostly required to pay a periodic sum, set by the court, that goes towards paying the creditors). Since 1996, Israeli personal bankruptcy law has shifted to a relatively debtor-friendly regime, not unlike the American model.<ref>{{cite web|last=EFRAT|first=RAFAEL|title=THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE ISRAELI BANKRUPTCY SYSTEM AS A REFLECTION OF SOCIETAL CHANGES|url=http://www.law.fsu.edu/journals/transnational/vol101/Efrat.pdf|publisher=[[Florida State University]]|accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=October 2017}}<!--Background and Ramifications sections both have several paragraphs without citations--> [[File:Pinckney's Treaty line 1795.png|thumb|350px|The boundary between the United States and Spanish Florida as set by "Pinckney's Treaty" (effective August 3, 1796) at 31°N, and Spain relinquished its claim on all territory north from that line to 32° 22′ to the United States.]] '''Pinckney's Treaty''', also commonly known as the '''Treaty of San Lorenzo''' or the '''Treaty of Madrid''', was signed in [[San Lorenzo de El Escorial]] on October 27, 1795 and established intentions of friendship between the [[United States]] and [[Spain]]. It also defined the border between the United States and [[Spanish Florida]], and guaranteed the United States navigation rights on the [[Mississippi River]]. With this agreement, the first phase of the ongoing border dispute between the two nations in this region, commonly called the [[West Florida Controversy]], came to a close.<ref>{{cite book| last=Bemis| first=Samuel Flagg| title=Pinckney's Treaty: A Study of America's Advantage from Europe's Distress, 1783–1800|orig-year=1926| edition=2nd| date=1960}}</ref>
The treaty's full title is '''Treaty of Friendship, Limits, and Navigation Between Spain and the United States'''. [[Thomas Pinckney]] negotiated the treaty for the United States and Don [[Manuel de Godoy]] represented Spain. It was presented to the [[United States Senate]] on February 26, 1796, and, after debate, was ratified on March 7, 1796. It was ratified by Spain on April 25, 1796 and ratifications were exchanged on that date. The treaty was proclaimed on August 3, 1796.
==Background== In 1763, [[Great Britain]] established two colonies—[[East Florida]] and [[West Florida]]—out of territory along the northern [[Gulf of Mexico]] coast taken from France and Spain following the [[French and Indian War]](the [[Seven Years' War]]). From Spain the British received all of Spanish Florida, and from France received the portion of [[Louisiana (New France)|French Louisiana]] east of the Mississippi River{{snd}}[[New Orleans]] plus all of French Louisiana west of the Mississippi had been secretly given to Spain the previous year. Both East and West Florida, never extensively colonized by the British, were [[Cession|ceded]] to Spain (who subsequently ruled both provinces as separate and apart from [[Louisiana (New Spain)|Louisiana]]) in the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|1783 Treaty of Paris]] at the end of the [[American Revolutionary War]]. When this transaction was made however, the boundaries of West Florida, which had changed while under British sovereignty, were not specified.
In 1763 West Florida's northern border was initially set at the [[31st parallel north]], but was moved in 1764 to 32° 22′ (the junction of the Mississippi and [[Yazoo River]]s, and location of present-day [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]]) in order to give the West Floridians more territory, including the [[Natchez District]] and the [[Tombigbee District]]. After reacquiring the colony, Spain insisted that its West Florida claim extended fully to 32° 22′, but the U.S. asserted that the land between 31° and 32° 22′ had always been British territory, and therefore rightfully belonged to the United States.
In 1784, the Spanish closed New Orleans to American goods coming down the Mississippi River. In 1795, the border was settled, and the US and Spain concluded a trade agreement. [[New Orleans]] was reopened, and Americans could transfer goods without paying cargo fees (right of deposit) when they transferred goods from one ship to another.<ref>Gerard H. Clarfield,"Victory in the West: A Study of the Role of Timothy Pickering in the Successful Consummation of Pinckney's Treaty." ''Essex Institute Historical Collections'' 101.4 (1965): 333+.</ref>
==Key treaty terms== [[File:Thomas Pinckney.jpg|right|thumb|180px|[[Thomas Pinckney]]]] [[File:Manuel de Godoy, por Antonio Carnicero (Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando).jpg|left|thumb|145px|[[Manuel Godoy]]]]
===Article II=== Established the southern boundary of the United States with the Spanish colonies of [[East Florida]] and [[West Florida]] as: a line beginning on the River Mississippi at the 31st parallel north (the 1763 line) drawn due east to the middle of the [[Chattahoochee River]] and, from there, downstream along the middle of the river to the junction with the [[Flint River (Georgia)|Flint River]] and, from there, due east to the headwaters of the [[St. Marys River (Florida-Georgia)|St. Marys River]] and, from there, along the middle of the channel to the [[Atlantic Ocean]].<ref name=mountvernon>{{Cite web| url=http://www.mountvernon.org/education/primary-sources-2/article/pinckneys-treaty/| title=Pinckney's Treaty| publisher=Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, George Washington's Mount Vernon| location=Mount Vernon, Virginia| accessdate=July 24, 2017}}</ref>
===Article III=== Stipulated that a joint Spanish–American team would [[Surveying|survey]] the [[Demarcation line|boundary line]].<ref name=mountvernon/>
===Article IV=== Established the western boundary of the United States with the Spanish colony of [[Louisiana (New Spain)|Louisiana]], as: the middle of the Mississippi River from the northern boundary of the United States (it was unknown at the time how far north the Mississippi extended) to the 31st degree north latitude; and that both Spanish subjects and U.S. citizens would have free navigation along the full length of the Mississippi, from its source to the Ocean.<ref name=mountvernon/>
===Article V=== The United States and Spain agreed not to incite native tribes to warfare and to promote mutually beneficial trade relationships the tribe on both sides of the border.<ref name=mountvernon/> Previously, Spain had been supplying [[weapon]]s to local tribes for many years. The agreement put the lands of the [[Chickasaw]] and [[Choctaw]] Nations of [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indians]] within the new boundaries of the United States.<ref name=greg_obrien>{{cite book| last = O'Brien| first = Greg| title = Choctaws in a Revolutionary Age, 1750–1830| year=2005| origyear = 2002 | url = | accessdate = | publisher = University of Nebraska Press| location = | chapter = Choctaw and Power| chapterurl = }}</ref>
===Articles VI and VII=== Spain and the United States also agreed to protect and defend the vessels of the other party anywhere within their jurisdictions and not to detain or embargo the other's citizens or vessels.<ref name=mountvernon/>
==Ramifications==
[[File:Ellicott's Stone 01.JPG| thumb|upright|left|220px|"[[Ellicott's Stone]]" [[boundary marker]] along the 31st parallel in present-day northern [[Mobile County, Alabama]]]] A joint Spanish–American team surveyed the boundary line. [[Andrew Ellicott]] served as the head of the U.S. contingent. The region that Spain relinquished its claim to through Pinckney's treaty was [[Organized incorporated territories of the United States|organized]] by Congress as [[Mississippi Territory]] on April 7, 1798. [[Natchez, Mississippi|Natchez]] was the territory's first and only capital.
Grant (1997) argues that the treaty was critical for the emergence of American expansionism (later known as "[[Manifest Destiny]]") because control of the Natchez and Tombigbee districts were needed for America's dominance of the Southwest. The collapse of Spanish power in the region was inevitable as Americans poured into the district, and very few Spaniards lived there. Spain gave up the area for reasons of international politics, not local unrest. Spanish rule was accepted by the French and British settlers near Natchez. Relations with the Indians were tranquil. However, with the loss of Natchez, Spain's frontier was no longer secure, and the rest of its territory was lost piecemeal.<ref>{{citejournal| last=Grant| first=Ethan| title=The Treaty of San Lorenzo and Manifest Destiny| journal=Gulf Coast Historical Review| date=Spring 1997| volume=12| issue=2| pages=44–57| location=Mobile, Alabama| publisher=History Dept. of the University of South Alabama|via=Tuskegee University Archives (2017)| url=http://archive.tuskegee.edu/gchr/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/gchr-12-02-1997.pdf| issn=0892-9025}}</ref>
Under the secret [[Third Treaty of San Ildefonso]] of October 1, 1800, Spanish Louisiana—comprising both the vast territory west of the Mississippi and New Orleans—was formally [[Retrocession|retroceded]] to France; but Spain continued to administer it. Again, as in 1783, the boundaries of the territory being exchanged were not specified. As a result, when France and the United States concluded the [[Louisiana Purchase]] in 1803, a new dispute, the second phase of the West Florida Controversy, arose.
This time, the disagreement was over whether the portion of West Florida first under British and then Spanish control since 1763 (between the Mississippi and Perdido Rivers) was included in the 1801 treaty, and thus the Louisiana Purchase. The United States laid claim to the region, asserting it was. Spain held that such a claim was baseless.<ref>Raymond A. Young,"Pinckney's Treaty - A New Perspective," ''Hispanic American Historical Review'', November 1963, Vol. 43 Issue 4, pp 526–539</ref><ref name =" Chambers">{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/westfloridaitsre00cham |title=West Florida and its relation to the historical cartography of the United States|first= Henry E.|last=Chambers| publisher=The Johns Hopkins Press|location = Baltimore, Maryland| date= May 1898}}</ref><ref name="Cox">{{cite book|title=The West Florida Controversy, 1798-1813 – a Study in American Diplomacy|author=[[Isaac Joslin Cox|Cox, Isaac Joslin]] | publisher=The Johns Hopkins Press|location = Baltimore, Maryland| date=1918}}</ref><ref name="Curry">{{cite journal|work=Magazine of American History|title=The Acquisition of Florida|first= J. L. M.|last=Curry|pages=286–301|volume=XIX|date=April 1888}}</ref> While the politicians squabbled, American and British settlers in the region declared an independent [[Republic of West Florida]] in 1810. Its [[capital city|capital]] was located at [[St. Francisville, Louisiana|St. Francisville]]. The Republic was quickly annexed by the U.S., and incorporated into the [[Territory of Orleans]], which [[Admission to the Union|joined the Union]] as the state of Louisiana in 1812. The present-day Louisiana [[Parish (administrative division)|civil parishes]] (equivalent to [[County (United States)|counties]] elsewhere in the U.S.) within the former republic are referred to as the "[[Florida Parishes]]."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/westflorida.html| title=The Republic of West Florida (1810)| website=exploresouthernhistory.com| accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Map to Illustrate the Acquisition of West Florida.jpg|thumb|400px|Annotated map of the territorial changes of [[British West Florida|British]] and [[Spanish West Florida]], 1767 to 1819.]] Also in 1812, the U.S. annexed the [[Mobile District]] of West Florida, between the Perdido and Pearl Rivers, declaring that it had been included in the Louisiana Purchase.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=002/llsl002.db&recNum=771 "An Act to enlarge the boundaries of the Mississippi territory"]</ref> Spain disputed this and maintained its claim over the area. The following year, a Federal statute was secretly enacted authorizing the president to take full possession of this area with the use of military force as deemed necessary.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=003/llsl003.db&recNum=513 "An Act authorizing the President of the United States to take possession of a tract of country lying south of the Mississippi territory and west of the river Perdido"]</ref> Accordingly, General [[James Wilkinson]] occupied this district with a military contingent; the Spanish colonial commandant offered no resistance. The annexed land was incorporated into the Mississippi Territory (and [[Partition (politics)|partitioned]] five years later when the [[Alabama Territory]] was established).
In 1819 the U.S. and Spain negotiated the [[Adams–Onís Treaty]], in which Spain ceded both West Florida and East Florida in their entirety to the United States. Since the mid-19th century, the southern (east–west) boundary established by Pinckney's Treaty has formed the [[U.S. state|state]] line between: *[[Florida]] and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] *Florida and [[Alabama]]{{snd}}between the Chattahoochee and [[Perdido River]]s *[[Louisiana]] and [[Mississippi]]{{snd}}between the [[Pearl River (Mississippi-Louisiana)|Pearl]] and Mississippi Rivers The line is not a state line between the Pearl and Perdido Rivers so as to provide Mississippi and Alabama with access to the Gulf of Mexico. {{Clear}}
==See also== *[[History of Alabama]] *[[History of Florida]] *[[History of Louisiana]] *[[History of Mississippi]] *[[List of United States treaties]] *[[Spain–United States relations]] {{portalbar|History|Geography|New Spain|United States}}
